;世界最高峰顶部的积雪比之前想象的要深得多一组中国科学家表示，这一发现可能会影响对气候变化的理解。

;

;周四，在非营利性国际科学期刊《冰冻圈》上发表的一份报告中，中国科学院的研究人员青藏高原研究所表示，珠穆朗玛峰山顶积雪的平均深度约为 9.5 米（31.1 英尺）。

;

;之前的估计深度在 0.92-3.5 米之间，研究人员表示，并补充说，这些测量结果不一致，并且具有“很大的不确定性”。

;

;“我们的测量显示……山顶的平均积雪深度惊人，约为 9.5 米，比之前的估计深得多， ”该研究所的杨伟教授在冰冻圈网站上的一段视频中说道。

;

;研究人员的这一发现是基于去年四月和五月珠穆朗玛峰北坡探险的结果。< /p>;

;他们使用探地雷达沿着海拔 7,000 米以上的山脊获取了数十个读数。

;

;读数显示雪和岩石表面之间存在很大差异，从而允许团队确定了两种材料之间的边界。

;

;报告称，总共集中在山顶的 26 个测量点显示积雪平均深度约为 9.5 米，并补充说结果范围在正负1.2米之内。

;

;“这种均匀性不仅表明了在这个有限区域内重复雷达测量的可靠性，而且还提供了对珠穆朗玛峰山脊相对平坦地形的深入了解， ”他们在论文中说道。

;

;杨表示，之前的测量工作受到“积雪密度、[测量]桩长和高海拔挑战”等因素的限制。

;

;在论文中，研究人员表示，比较不同时期的积雪深度可能有助于了解人类引起的气候变化对喜马拉雅山极高海拔地区的影响。

;

;“珠穆朗玛峰上的积雪和冰川是他们说：“我们是气候变化的哨兵，因此为了解如此极高的海拔地区正在发生的气候变化及其对亚洲水塔可能产生的广泛影响提供了一个潜在的自然平台。”他们说。

;

;他们说雪芯钻探等等需要对珠穆朗玛峰进行探地雷达测量，以了解积雪的变化情况。

;

;由于雪位、重力偏差和光折射的变化，人们对珠穆朗玛峰的确切海拔存在分歧。其他因素。这一新发现意味着珠穆朗玛峰的真实高度可能会发生变化。

;

;研究人员表示，珠穆朗玛峰是喜马拉雅山脉的最高峰，但顶峰的高度一直不一致。

;

; >;

;2020年，北京和加德满都联合公布的最新测量值为8850米，略高于尼泊尔此前的测量值，比中国当时的评估值高出约4米。

;由于持续的热浪和威胁，中国当局在周末发布了一系列天气警告严重洪涝增加了农作物和电网受损的风险。

;

;农业农村部和中国气象局周日警告称，持续炎热天气可能会损害水稻生产，有关部门应确保田间安全有足够的水来降低气温并防止过早成熟，特别是在南方。

;

;预计未来 10 天内，中国南方大部分地区的气温将保持在 35 摄氏度（95 华氏度）以上，并且还会上升湖南、江西、浙江、福建等省份部分地区最高气温达40摄氏度。

;

;中国气象局周日上午还单独发布了三级高温黄色警报，警告人们河北、河南、山西、浙江、福建、内蒙古等地预计气温将突破40摄氏度。

;

;建议受影响地区人员避免户外活动，以及必须在室内工作的人员

;

;由于电力需求给电网带来压力，它还提醒当局警惕火灾。

;

;自那以后，严重的热浪席卷了中国大部分地区。 6月，预报员称极端天气可能比去年持续两个多月的热浪更严重。

;

;同时，水利部对内蒙古九个省份的洪水发出警报、辽宁、吉林、黑龙江、安徽、江苏、湖北、重庆、贵州。仅江苏省就有约6000名堤防检查人员在执勤。

;

;据称，周四以来的强降雨导致江苏、江西、辽宁、贵州和内蒙古北部的12条河流水位超过警戒水位。

;

; >;

;根据中国气象局周六发布的《中国气候变化蓝皮书（2023）》，气候变化对中国的影响日趋严重，去年夏季平均气温、沿海海平面和冰川退缩。

;

;上海新闻媒体澎湃新闻援引国家气候中心副主任袁家双的话说，中国气温上升速度明显高于全球平均水平气候系统持续变暖。

;

;蓝皮书称，1901年至2022年，中国年平均气温每10年上升0.16摄氏度，高于全球平均水平。

;

;中国气象局气象服务部首席专家周冰告诉澎湃新闻，高温天气也可能是厄尔尼诺现象造成的。

;

;厄尔尼诺现象是由于气候变暖而自然发生的气候模式。热带太平洋中部和东部的海洋表面温度。它通常每两到七年发生一次，持续九到十二个月。

;

;世界气象组织周二表示，热带太平洋地区七年来首次出现厄尔尼诺现象，设定了周表示，厄尔尼诺现象预计将在夏季给中国北部、中部、东部和西北地区的部分地区带来极高的气温，并使中国的气温升高。

;

;国家气候中心气候变化影响与适应办公室首席专家徐红梅表示，中国亟需加大对气候变化适应能力的投入。

;

; >;

;“特别是要加强全球变暖对我国典型脆弱地区影响的监测。”澎湃新闻援引徐的话说。

;英国高级政界人士周日呼吁 BBC 迅速调查一名主要主持人的指控向一名青少年支付露骨照片的费用。

;

;英国小报《太阳报》报道称，这名男主持人从 2020 年开始向一名青少年支付 35,000 英镑（45,000 美元），之后这家由公共资助的国家广播公司面临压力。 17 岁。

;

;明星和年轻人的身份均未确定。在社交媒体上对主持人身份的猜测中，BBC 的几位最知名明星发声称这不是他们。

;

;尽管英国的同意性行为年龄是 16 岁，但这是一个制作或拥有 18 岁以下人士的不雅图像属于犯罪行为。

;

;政府部长维多利亚·阿特金斯 (Victoria Atkins) 表示，这些指控“非常严重”。她告诉天空新闻，“随着公众关注度和担忧的增加，BBC 将必须迅速采取行动来处理这些指控，并说明他们正在采取哪些措施来调查这些指控”。

;

;Rachel Reeves反对党工党的经济发言人表示，BBC 需要“加快进程”并“让他们的房子井然有序”。

;

;这名年轻人的母亲告诉《太阳报》，她看到了主持人的照片在她孩子的手机上，他“穿着内衣坐在家里的沙发上”，她说她被告知这是“某种视频通话中的照片”。

;

;《太阳报》说这名青少年的家人于 5 月 19 日向 BBC 投诉。

;

;BBC 在整个周六的新闻公报中报道了这一事件。

;

;新西兰广播公司因“亲克里姆林宫垃圾”而停职记者关于乌克兰

;

;在克莱夫·迈里 (Clive Myrie) 主持的《十点新闻》中，特约记者露西·曼宁 (Lucy Manning) 表示：“我认为这对 BBC 来说非常严重，让我们毫不掩饰这一点。

;

; “据了解，这位主持人不会在不久的将来播出，但我们还没有被告知，我们已经询问过，BBC 也没有告诉我们是否已经正式停播。

;

;“BBC 需要回答是否应该更早进行调查，是否应该更彻底，以及对于与此无关的其他主持人是否公平，因为他们的名字现在出现在了节目中。”头条新闻。”曼宁表示，她认为这“确实有可能严重损害 BBC 的声誉”。

;

;《太阳报》报道称，虽然主持人停播，但他并未被停职。

;

;周六，在社交媒体上的猜测中，一些 BBC 明星发推文表示，他们不是《太阳报》故事中心的主持人。

;

;瑞兰·克拉克 (Rylan Clark) 发推文：“不知道为什么我的名字会流传开来，但这是《太阳报》上的那个故事——那不是我，宝贝。我目前正在意大利为 BBC 拍摄一档节目，所以请把我的名字从你们嘴里说出来。”

;

;杰里米·瓦恩 (Jeremy Vine) 发推文说：“只是想说，我非常期待在周一——无论新闻中的“BBC 主持人”是谁，我都像 Rylan 之前一样向你传达同样的信息：那肯定不是我。”

;

;加里·莱因克尔 (Gary Lineker) 在推特上写道：“我不想让仇恨者失望但这不是我。”

;

;尼基·坎贝尔似乎暗示他已就与该报道有关的事情与警方联系。

;

;他在推特上发布了一张屏幕截图，其中带有大都会警察局的徽标和文字：“感谢您联系伦敦警察厅报告您的罪行。”

;

;随着球员和明星团结在加里·莱因克尔身后，BBC 危机升级

;

;他在推文中写道：“我认为表明立场很重要。社交媒体上这样的人太多了。感谢朋友们的支持。”

;

;BBC 发言人表示：“我们非常严肃地对待任何指控，并制定了积极处理这些指控的流程。

;

;“作为其中的一部分，如果我们收到需要进一步调查或检查的信息，我们将采取措施做到这一点。这包括积极尝试与那些与我们联系的人交谈，以寻求更多细节和了解情况。

;

;“如果我们的尝试没有得到答复或没有收到进一步的联系，可能会限制我们取得进展的能力但这并不意味着我们的调查停止。

;

;“如果在任何时候发现或提供新信息（包括通过报纸），我们将根据内部流程采取适当行动。 ”

;中国已完成即将部署的水下监听装置的现场测试和评估据中国极地研究院称，这一举动预计将给北冰洋带来进一步的紧张局势，该地区在全球权力博弈中变得越来越重要，因为它战略位置、自然资源和新航线的潜力。

;

;计划中的大规模监听网络收集的声学信息可用于广泛的应用，包括“冰下通信、导航和定位” 、目标探测和海洋环境参数重建，”该研究所在上个月发表在《中国极地研究杂志》上的一项研究中表示。

;

;中国科学家和工程师在一块大块上安装了“极地冰下浅表声监测浮标系统” 2021 年 8 月 9 日，北冰洋偏远地区出现浮冰。

;

;“[这里]是世界上气候变化最严重的地区之一，”该研究所表示。

;该系统携带了多种仪器，但最重要的是矢量水听器，其多个传感器排列在不同方向，用于测量声波的压力和质点运动。

;

;声压数据可以是用于追踪鲸鱼、海豹和其他发声源。水粒子的水平和垂直振动可以帮助科学家了解海流、波浪和海底等海洋状况。

;

;新鲜数据通过卫星传输到中国的指挥中心。

;

;当他们离开时，科学家们并不确定这些硬件能在恶劣的极地环境中生存多久。但其性能超出了他们的预期。

;

;该研究所表示，“系统中配备的所有传感器都超出了设计指标17.4%。”

;

;硬件采用成熟的技术构建

;

;“可大规模用于北冰洋环境监测网络建设”。

;

;中国政府已进行多次调查，并部署了许多该研究所表示，该研究所从未在那里安装监听装置，包括浮标。

;

;该研究所表示，部分原因是在无人值守的情况下对北极水域进行自动监测存在技术挑战。例如，该系统的长期运行需要能够承受低温的锂电池，并且有足够的能量为大量电子设备供电以及与卫星的定期通信。

;

;地缘政治可能也是一个促成因素。

;

;美国政府强烈反对中国在该地区的活动，该地区被冰盖覆盖，可供核潜艇转运和隐藏。

;

;俄罗斯也有类似的担忧，尽管近年来其立场有所缓和。

;

;“我们认为与中国合作伙伴在开发北海航线过境潜力方面的合作大有希望，”俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京告诉中国国家主席习近平3月份在莫斯科举行的一次会议期间。

;

;据该研究所称，随着全球气温上升，中国对北极的兴趣也随之增加。

;

;预计冰盖的快速融化将导致东亚、欧洲乃至北美之间的海上贸易航线大大缩短，使中国参与北极事务的动力更大。

;

;“东北航道的开通和商业使用已成为现实。”该研究所表示。 “我们的极地研究起步较晚。”

;

;俄罗斯“间谍”鲸鱼在瑞典水面

;

;在极地研究所的测试中，矢量水听器每两小时启动一次，探测感兴趣的目标试图节省能源。

;

;在持续三个多月的试验中，它检测到航运、石油和天然气勘探等人类活动可能产生的大声低频噪音。

;

; p>;

;数据流还帮助中国科学家更好地了解冰的形成和融化对声音的影响。

;

;当海水结冰时，它会释放盐水并改变海水的盐度和密度。周围的水域。

;

;据该研究所称，水听器数据量比其他传感器收集的数据量大 1,000 倍以上。

;

;一些研究人员抱怨发送成本太高

;

;该研究所在测试中使用了美国通信卫星服务。

;

;“铱星通信系统目前主要用于北极高纬度地区，该研究所称，由于近年来缺乏卫星更新和维护，通信成本高，信号不稳定。

;

;它表示，中国的极地监听网络很可能会转向中国的北斗卫星进行通信.

;

;目前尚不清楚该网络是否已经在建设中、何时完成以及规模有多大。该研究所没有回应询问。

;

;华盛顿智库战略与国际研究中心 (CSIS) 在 4 月份的一份报告中表示，中国的北极研究重点是推进科学知识，包括海冰成分、太空天气和海洋生物。

;

;但战略与国际研究中心表示，中国在北极的研究考察还涉及广泛的海洋学调查和声学建模，这可能有助于中国海军活动。

;

;中国在北极有两个永久研究站，一个位于挪威斯瓦尔巴群岛，另一个位于冰岛。

;

;北京计划扩大其在该地区的陆基存在，但面临来自美国和其他国家越来越多的障碍

;

;2018年，中国极地研究院试图购买芬兰拉普兰机场。据报道，芬兰政府在美国的压力下终止了该交易。

; Sun, 09 Jul 2023 18:20:06 +0800 Hong Kong youth addicted to internet need to be understood instead of judged, experts sayhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/society/article/3227073/dissatisfaction-reality-hong-kong-youth-addicted-internet-need-be-understood-instead-judged-experts?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.09 18:00;
;;

;香港人 June* 被送去接受心理咨询时只有八岁，因为她逃学，没日没夜地盯着电脑。

;

;当她回到学校时，再次面对老师和同学，她感到很痛苦。这让她回到了虚拟世界。

;

;在她的在线游戏和同人社区中，她结交了朋友，分享了她的数字艺术作品，并感到更加被理解，尽管她经常忘记时间并熬夜。

;

;“在互联网上，我可以选择做什么、与谁交谈以及谈论什么，”现年 14 岁的 June 回忆道。“没有人可以强迫我做任何事情。”

;

;上个月，关注儿童和青少年的非政府组织香港游乐场协会（HKPA）采访了超过 4,000 名 18 岁以下的香港人，发现 13.7% 的人有很高的网络成瘾倾向。中学生中，超过15%被发现属于高风险。

;

;暑假网络警告，网上诈骗者对香港儿童进行攻击

;

;前线青年工作者和学者已呼吁更好地理解网络成瘾，并以更加同理心的方式看待表现出网络成瘾行为的儿童和青少年的心理需求。

;

;专家表示，成瘾的迹象包括渴望、失控和个人切割远离家人和朋友，并在不上网时表现出退缩症状，例如颤抖和焦虑。

;

;否则，虽然也令人担忧，但年轻人可能只是严重依赖互联网。

;

; p>;

;香港基督教服务处网上成瘾辅导中心负责人邓俊宇表示，许多孩子的成瘾行为背后隐藏着现实生活的困扰。

;

;“我希望更多人能够明白这不一定是上瘾，而是对现实不满意的结果。”他说。

;

;花大量时间上网的孩子往往在学校表现不佳，没有技能或天赋，缺乏同伴支持，这些都会导致自尊心低落。

;

;“他们需要朋友、幸福、满足感，”他说。 “他们希望有人理解并接受他们本来的样子，但现实世界并不总能满足这些核心需求。”

;

;唐说，中心的咨询工作重点是帮助年轻人探索更多选择，重建现实

;

;“我们不愿意使用‘成瘾’这个词，因为它带有标签，而且对年轻人缺乏了解，”他说。 “通过用‘不平衡’来代替，我们希望让他们感到被理解、被接受，并有动力去改变自己的习惯。”

;

;去年开始去中心的June，逐渐走出了自己的外壳。 Counselling and antidepressants from her psychiatrist have helped her deal with her social phobia.

;

;Although she still spent an hour or two on the internet every day, she was no longer afraid to leave home or talk to people, and hoped to pursue her passion for digital art.

;

;'Trauma can last a lifetime': backlash as Hong Kong mother withdraws smartphone

;

;'Loss of control a key feature'

;

;HKPA project officer Venus Lee Yan-yi said parents worried about the amount of time their children spent online and their school grades, and this often led to clashes.

;

;“If parents always assume using the internet is a bad thing, their children will avoid talking to them about it, even when they face cyber risks,” she said.

;

;Addiction counsellor Chau Yuk-shan of the Tung Wah Group of Hospitals' Integrated Centre on Addiction Prevention and Treatment, said almost three in four of the young people he counselled were addicted to mobile gaming, experienced constant cravings and suffered many consequences including health problems and family conflicts.

;

;Most struggled to understand their condition, and counselling focused on helping them realise the consequences.

;

;About a quarter of those who came to the centre also had psychiatric disorders, including depression and autism, among others, he added.

;

;The World Health Organization listed gaming disorder as a mental health condition in 2018, but debates remain over the diagnosis and definition of internet addiction, or excessive internet use.

;

;Dr Chan Kai-tai, clinical associate professor of the University of Hong Kong's department of psychiatry, said: “The definition of internet addiction varies across disciplines, but loss of control remains the core feature.”

;

;He said it was important to set up a cross-disciplinary platform to understand internet addiction better and develop strategies to deal with it.

;

;“As we talk about finding a balance in life, where exactly is the balance, and who gets to decide? Young people, who are the digital natives, should be involved in this discussion because they experience the biggest impact,” he said.

;

;Instead of regulating screen time, he stressed that the focus should be on advocating healthy use of the internet, with a conscious boundary drawn between the physical and virtual worlds, and digital devices being treated as tools.

;

;“We also have to be aware of, and widely discuss how digitalisation impacts humans as a whole before humanity becomes an artefact in the museums,” he added.

;

;'A feeling she can't process': Hong Kong dad on helping child with mental health

;

;Professor Matthew Lee Kwok-on, chair professor of information systems and e-commerce at City University, who has been researching addiction in the past decade, believed it was part of a bigger problem in a new digital world.

;

;“The Hong Kong population lacks digital literacy, meaning the right knowledge, skill and attitude to use digital technology … especially how to keep ourselves safe, including protecting privacy and our physical and mental health while using it,” he said.

;

;He added there was a need for more research and education to cultivate healthy and productive use of technology.

;

;“The key is to develop a self-regulation mechanism, so that individuals are aware of their behaviour and the potential consequences … and it's important to acknowledge that the gadgets are not a scourge.”

;

;*Name changed to protect interviewee's identity.

;A top Hong Kong government adviser has said the police's HK$1 million (US$127,700) bounties on eight wanted opposition figures underlined the government's commitment to targeting activity that endangered national security and warned businesses to be wary of being linked to a group of supporter stores that funded them.

;

;Executive Council convenor Regina Ip Lau Suk-yee on Sunday appealed to retailers not to identify themselves as part of the “yellow economic circle”, a loose business coalition that backed the 2019 anti-government protests and alleged to have conspired to raise funds on behalf of one of the eight wanted activists.

;

;Ip said the price on activists' heads was a global warning to those who financed people who compromised national security.

;

;“There are not just 'yellow economic circle', but also other activities that transfer capitals to exiled activists. The force needs to investigate such activities and cut the financing channels,” Ip said in a television interview.

;

;Ip highlighted businesses that shipped Hong Kong-style foods for tea parties overseas, which were used to back illegal activities because the events were held in an attempt to persuade foreign politicians to back sanctions against the city and mainland China.

;

;“It turns out that the parties involved brainwashing … laying blame on the Chinese and the SAR governments, demanding that people with votes go to the UK to ask parliamentary members to sanction Hong Kong,” Ip said.

;

;She added that people would not be in violation of national security law if they did not know in advance that the food they sold would be used at events designed to damage the country.

;

;But she added: “Since there are these risks, don't call yourself a 'yellow economic circle', it will not help your business at all.”

;

;She was speaking after Hong Kong national security police earlier arrested five people from disbanded opposition party Demosisto on allegations they conspired to raise funds on behalf of Nathan Law Kwun-chung, a former lawmaker and one of the eight wanted activists.

;

;Hong Kong's most wanted: a look at police bounties for notorious crimes

;

;Among the five was a director of a company that runs the Mee app, which is associated with businesses that are part of the “yellow economic circle”.

;

;Mee, which offers group purchases of festive delicacies such as mooncakes and rice dumplings, was not available from major app stores soon after the arrests were made.

;

;Ip suggested some “yellow shops” might have closed in the wake of the announcements of the rewards and related arrests because of a lack of business.

;

;“Some of them could not maintain their business. If one carries on the business just because of political colour, it will not last for long. Business is business,” she said.

;

;Ip maintained the bounties were “necessary” as they sent a clear message to the world that the eight wanted people were still a threat to China's national security.

;

;“Foreign countries will not help us to arrest them. But those activists continue to organise events to confuse people under the name of 'freedom and democracy'. We need to send a message to the world they are in fact committing crimes,” Ip said.

;

;4 ex-members of Hong Kong's Demosisto arrested for 'yellow-circle' fundraising

;

;The eight wanted opposition figures besides Law are Dennis Kwok Wing-hang and Ted Hui Chi-fung, trade unionist Mung Siu-tat, lawyer Kevin Yam Kin-fung, and activists Finn Lau Cho-dik, Anna Kwok Fung-yee and Elmer Yuan Gong-yi.

;

;They were last known to be living in the United States, Britain, Australia and Canada.

;

;Police last week announced the unprecedented HK$1 million rewards for information leading to the arrest and prosecution of the eight.

;

;Seven of the group were accused of appealing for international sanctions against Hong Kong.

;

;City leader John Lee Ka-chiu earlier said they should be treated like “rats in the street that should be avoided for our sake.”

;

;Financial Secretary Paul Chan Mo-po on Sunday said he had met some start-ups and technological enterprises during his trip to Shanghai, adding that the companies were considering expanding into global markets through Hong Kong.

;

;“In terms of attracting enterprises and investment, we have received a lot of positive responses,” he wrote in his weekly blog.

;

;Peak economic growth for Hong Kong dependent on external factors: Paul Chan

;During his three-day trip to Shanghai that wrapped up on Saturday, Chan also met senior city officials and spoke to the top management of the New Development Bank.

;The Shanghai-based bank was set up in 2015 by Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa, known as the BRICS countries, to finance infrastructure and development projects.

;

;The trip was also Chan's first visit to the city since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic back in 2020.

;

;It included stop-offs at company offices and research centres, as well as sit-down exchanges, which had all helped the minister to gain a greater understanding of emerging start-ups and tech firms located across the border, he said.

;

;“They recognised the advantages of Hong Kong's 'one country two systems' and internationalisation, and expressed a strong interest in expanding their global markets with Hong Kong as their base,” he added, referring to the city's governing principle.

;Hong Kong on track to become 'world's leading green finance centre': Paul Chan

;Chan also gave a keynote speech at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference 2023 and addressed the Asian Logistics, Maritime and Aviation Conference Satellite Conference, all while promoting Hong Kong's financial and high value-added services to key players in Shanghai's commercial and industrial sectors.

;

;“The visit shows that Hong Kong has been heading in the right direction to develop its innovation and technology,” he said.

;

;But the minister warned the city should avoid becoming complacent and the financial hub needed to snatch opportunities to “stay ahead” of the competition.

;

;Authorities said the office had contacted more than 150 enterprises within the first six months of its establishment.

;Chan on Sunday also devoted part of his blog to domestic efforts to boost consumption that were first outlined in February's budget speech, vowing that developing the economy was the government's “core mission”.

;He encouraged residents to go out and enjoy the Harbour Chill Carnival, an event under the “Happy Hong Kong” government drive to boost local spending and get people smiling after the pandemic.

; Sun, 09 Jul 2023 18:20:06 +0800 Huawei Cloud team says AI model produces faster, more accurate weather forecastshttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/science/article/3226955/huawei-cloud-team-says-ai-model-produces-faster-more-accurate-weather-forecasts?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.09 16:00;
;;

;Researchers from Chinese cloud company Huawei say they have developed an AI-based global weather algorithm that can provide faster and more accurate forecasts than the traditional method.

;

;They say the model, called Pangu-Weather, can produce forecasts in seconds, including humidity, wind speed, temperature, sea level pressure and even disaster warnings.

;

;It is the first such model using artificial intelligence that has produced more accurate results than the numerical prediction method used by mainstream weather forecast services around the world.

;

;In a paper in peer-reviewed journal Nature on Wednesday, the team said their experiments had shown the model was “10,000 times faster” than the one used by the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) – the most powerful weather forecasting tool currently in use.

;

;Pangu-Weather focuses on medium-range forecasting. Unlike nowcasting, which provides a detailed description of the current weather across local areas, medium-range forecasting covers a period of up to two weeks and plays an important role in disaster prevention.

;

;Until now, AI-based forecasting has been inferior to numerical weather prediction for medium- and long-term forecasts. That method represents weather conditions as little squares on a map and uses maths to figure out how they change from one state to another. But it is computationally expensive and time consuming.

;

;“When a problem involves complex mathematical mechanisms, large amounts of data and it is hard for people to find specific solutions, we think this problem is very suitable for AI,” Dr Tian Qi, lead scientist on the Huawei Cloud project, said in an earlier statement.

;

;He said meteorological research was a great field for AI to play a role in.

;

;World swelters to unofficial hottest day ever Monday then gets hotter Tuesday

;

;One new algorithm developed for the model adapts to the Earth's coordinate system to handle complex and uneven 3D weather data. The team also used new computational strategies with less iterations to cut cumulative errors.

;

;To train the model for output at specific time intervals, the researchers used 100 epochs (cycles) with hourly samples of weather data from 1979 to 2021. Each of the sub-models had 16 days of training on 192 V100 graphics cards.

;

;Huawei Cloud said in a statement on Thursday that Pangu-Weather could “now complete 24-hour global weather forecasts in just 1.4 seconds on a single V100 graphics card” – 10,000 times faster than traditional numerical prediction.

;

;While other AI models have been mostly unable to predict extreme and unusual weather such as typhoons, Pangu-Weather achieved more accurate forecast results in testing compared with the ECMWF system.

;

;“Our algorithm achieved high accuracy in tracking 88 named tropical cyclones in 2018, including some (for example, Typhoon Kong-rey and Typhoon Yutu) that remain a challenge for the world's best tracking systems,” Tian said in the paper.

;

;“This shows Pangu-Weather not only produces strong quantitative results but also preserves sufficient details for investigating certain extreme weather events.”

;

;The China Meteorological Administration has confirmed that it used Pangu-Weather to successfully forecast, five days before, the path of Typhoon Mawar off the east of Taiwan in May. The typhoon, which moved over the Pacific, was the most powerful tropical storm seen so far this year.

;

;Elon Musk says he has faith in China's ability to develop artificial intelligence

;

;Huawei Cloud unveiled a platform for AI models – called Pangu Models 3.0 – at a developer conference held by the tech giant in the southern Chinese city of Dongguan on Friday. It includes a natural language processing model that could be used for marketing, a computational vision model for image detection, as well as Pangu-Weather, a scientific computing model that the company says has applications in weather forecasting but also medicine design.

;

;“We aim to use a large model as a foundation to grow other applications on top of it,” Tian said in the statement. “If we can solve one problem, we can quickly apply the solution to similar problems elsewhere.”
